captions.text: On this episode of Roadkill we're gonna show you
the entire buildup of my '55 Chevy Bel Air. With hemi!

So here's how I ended up with a '55 Chevy:
when I was in high school a buddy mine named
Clay Baber

had a '56 Bel Air and it was a
four-door and it wasn't a gasser

but the body style left an impression on
me.
So that and seeing the movie Two-Lane Blacktop just
made me obsessed with this body style and

getting one of these cars in my garage
at some point in my life. A year and a half

that's how long it's been since we ran
up to Oregon in episode

8 of Roadkill and took his bare '55 Chevy
body,
plopped it onto a Jim Meyer racing gasser chassis and then came home

and almost did nothing with it, and so
now we're going to force them to get it
done. We gotta jam this thing together in

15 days in time for the Grand National
Roadster Show.
So she looks different from the last time you saw your because all the rust is gone.

That's a fiberglass front clip which we
bought to shave weight.
Here's the Jim Meyer bitching gasser chassis.

So far we've move the firewall back to
actually fit the Hemi in here, started a
roll cage,

but essentially it needs everything. So
the car over the last year and a half
hasn't

had a ton of work done to it but it hasn't
exactly set around either.

It's got all new floor boards which we
got from classic industries and had our
friends at Hot Rods & Hobbies

weld in the car so we've got a solid
foundation that we can now use to weld
our roll cage into,
which we got from Chris Staulson's Chassis works so the car is solid it's

basically a roller. The body is mostly
intact.

We've just got to do everything else to
make it run. It's a ton of work,
but it's not impossible. I predict a lot of all nighters and

broken knuckles and stuff like that but we
may end up divorced from our wives on

this deal, but I will finally get to
drive my car

hopefully on my birthday. Yeah I mean
when you're gonna build a car in

15 days you need a list because you're
you're never gonna remember anything

even with the list but this at least
keeps everyone on track

but the big thing is is it reminds you
need to order parts

because we don't have anything we need
to build this right now and its day one
and we need to overnight stuff basically.
You're good.
The reason that we needed to dummy the engine in the car  are: 1
we need to measure up drive shaft links so we can get that coming

and then we had to put the steering
column in the car the main reason for

that is to see what our obstacles are for
making headers.

See the problem here is with the
steering box when this is where this

needs to go and I'm not even lined up
with the port this needs to come up.
Even this side is nightmare it goes straight into the frame rail

but way more workable than your side. Our
second major hurdle is figuring out how
to build a set of headers for this thing

because nobody makes headers to put in a
Hemi in a '55

so we got a bunch of bends from Hedman
Headers we're

gonna chop them up right now and see if
our engine location is gonna work with
our steering.
This is our test pipe right here.
Give me the cold end.

If we make this work then we can leave
the engine where it's at and we don't
have to hack up the rest of the car,

which will save us days I'm worried it's
gonna hit
in here if we do that. Go...like this.
I'll put more of an angle on it this way.

We've never made headers before but
so far it's proving
easy all you need is flanges and a zillion tub bends,

and a whole lotta love by cutting
slicing, dicing, pie cutting, wedging pizza,
cutting,
and figuring. And a great attitude.

Last night I had an epiphany about how
to get that one header tube

around the steering column and that
sorta broke this project wide open

because we're thinking we're gonna have
to drop the steering box to raise the

engine or do something to get headers on
the car.

So Finny and I stayed really late last
night getting really excited about
building sets of headers,

and we're trying to make them perfectly
symmetrical on both sides so its got that cool
gasser evil look.
The deal is when you cut the tube

in a straight piece it becomes perfectly
round if you cut it

off square in the middle of a turn then
it becomes a big

oval like this there's no way to put
them together.

That makes us more of a challenge. They
say the definition of insanity is doing

the same thing over and over and over
again and expecting a different result
kinda what we've been doing here today.
Yeah how many of those bends have we used like there's your Headman header hemi '55 Chevy kit
and there's the mistakes. Oh those aren't mistakes
those are fine tuning adjustments. Dude! Just set it on there.
That is gasser adjustments right there. Look at that.
Ya us! Yay us!

That's pretty big that's what we have
not done before
yeah they definitely are gasser looking headers for sure. They have a little zoomy
action going to them and then the gasser thing.
Look at that! Yeah! Oh man.
That's the reason we're here that is a giant engine. I know.

It looks even better with the headers
doesn't it?
Wow it just got real.
This side not so impressive. This side:
schwing!

A lot of people think that we fabricate
drama for Roadkill that we're always on a

tight schedule and why don't we plan

here is the reality of our life: we're
working on

Then we've also got the muscle truck
that's getting MSD fuel injection on it
for an editorial story,
and over here we've got my Super Bee Crusher Camaro that Grant is prepping to
take to the drag strip.

Next week actually yeah which is going
to take 3 days out of the schedule
to go have to test those two things.

Less talking more working there are 11

In order to complete the entire car

and so I needed help right now video

It'll be a big accomplishment if

tilt I think we have to cut back here.

end.

and we're thinking it's become we tried to

and so Todd is gonna grind on it try and

Yes and big time.
Ooh but...yeah.
(laugh) Look at that. That is cool.
We need to sit behind the wheel.
That is so evil looking pretty cool.
Way too high.

way too high but I get to see. The next
like big moment will be

firing it off. Yeah we finished the headers
we're dead tired, but we loaded the
engine up

took it straight to the dyno. The dyno

because we thought we were really close

but the moment they turn the water on

and it's just peeing out onto the floor
of the dyno cell
which is no good so gonna have to buy a new water pump.
680 pound feet of torque.
That's going to be fun.

Now that it's broken we're gonna drain the

that's going to give us a visual chuck of how the bearings are doing in this thing
right now,
and if this thing is full of you know metal then basically your engine's eating
itself alive and you need to take it apart
and start over. Ours is not doing that
so we get to keep going with this build.
I'm at a loss right now

we broke the engine in made a couple
power pulls to 6,000 rpm.

It makes great power and puffed a little
bit a smoke out of one breather

at the end of a pull. Changed the oil fired it
back up its down on power and
smoking out of the breeders as if isn't wounded but we did a compression check it

checked out fine we cut the oil filter
rope,
drained the oil everything looked fine. Dunno what's going on.

Every dyno test is an emotional roller
coaster
you know strap the engine down cross your fingers that it's gonna run properly
and that the work you've done is correct. 5 hours ago
we found blown head gaskets. Engine's back together now.
Hopefully we're heroes.

We broke it we fixed it and made more
power than actually even

requested. It was an amazing feeling
of accomplishment

to overcome that obstacle we made 700
horsepower and seven hundred-pound
feet of torque. The problem was our one day dyno test took two days
and now there was not hope of making the Roadster show.

When finnegan brought the engine
back from the dyno we had the body of
the chassis
we needed to paint the underside and do things like that and so we're able
to mock the engine and finally get in our bitchin T56 Magnum

transmission which is a double overdrive
6 speed from American powertrain.

When May 2014 rolled around we still

Show

but we had another scheme we were gonna

and the honest to god truth is i'm going to ignore this cuz this is

cuz you need that to sand the dash

I'm insuring it's got insurance just no registration.

that's powder coated and has a fuel pump

because it's more san-o and
it runs better.

the gasket between the engine block and the cylinder head literally blows 
apart, this creates a lack of compression. It's usually caused by 
overheating or overworking the engine but can be from improperly torqued 
head bolts, etc.

comments.author: Best Backwards Driver Best Backwards Driver

comments.text:
When you take the filter media out of the filter, cut it out with a razor 
knife, you can then squeeze all of the oil out in a vise, and really see 
what's in it better. Not saying Finnegan didn't know that, but it's a trick 
I often use at work. The wet darker colored filter media along with oil 
that coats everything obscures a lot. I'm late to this show, but I love it. 
Glad to finally see that badass Bel Air. Nice job!﻿
